title: How to Serve Smoked Salmon

steps.headline: Get cold smoked salmon if you’re looking for a silkier texture.
steps.description: Cold smoked salmon refers to salmon that is smoked at any temperature lower than 80 °F (27 °C), typically for 15 hours or more. Since the salmon is never really heated, it maintains a lot of its raw textures, and tends to be smoother than hot smoked salmon. It’s most commonly-used on bagels, crackers, or consumed on its own as a simple snack.Tip: Cold smoked salmon can be consumed without cooking or heating it. Any dangerous bacteria will make the fish go bad, so as long as it’s not rotting or past its expiration date, you don’t need to cook it. Cold smoked salmon is often marketed as Nova. Nova is simply short for Nova Scotia, and these cold smoked salmons were caught off of the eastern shores of North America and Canada.

steps.headline: Choose hot smoked salmon if you really love the smoky flavor.
steps.description: Hot smoked salmon is smoked for a shorter period of time at a higher temperature. Typically, it’s smoked around 145 °F (63 °C) for about 8 hours. Since this process thoroughly cooks the salmon, the meat tends to be flakier and firmer, resulting in a final product that resembles grilled salmon. Hot smoked salmon is often used as an ingredient in salads, salads, and casseroles. Like cold smoked salmon, hot smoked salmon can also be consumed on its own without additional cooking. Hot smoked salmon tends to be smokier than cold smoked salmon. If you’re a fan of barbeque, you’ll love hot smoked salmon.

steps.headline: Opt for lox or gravlax for a more traditional texture.
steps.description: Lox is style of uncooked salmon that isn’t actually smoked, but is often marketed alongside smoked salmon as an alternative. It’s traditionally put on bagels and has a silky texture and salty flavor. Gravlax isn’t smoked either, but is often sold alongside smoked salmon. It’s basically lox that has been cured with spices and seasoning. These are both great alternatives if you want some smoked salmon but can’t find it at your local deli or grocery store. While these salmons aren’t smoked, their similarity to smoked salmon is unmistakable. You can substitute any recipe that calls for smoked salmon with lox or gravlax. Gravlax is a traditional Nordic dish, but it may be a little harder to get your hands on than lox or smoked salmon. Any Scandinavian recipes that call for gravlax can substitute cold or hot smoked salmon.

steps.headline: Cut your baguette into 24 thin slices.
steps.description: Place your baguette on a cutting board and grab a serrated knife. Hold the baguette in place with your nondominant hand and use your knife to cut 24 individual slices of bread. Start on the end of your loaf and work your way to the other end of the bread. Avoid cutting pieces thicker than 1.5 in (3.8 cm).

steps.headline: Place your slices of bread on a baking sheet and brush them with oil.
steps.description: Lay down a sheet of aluminum foil on a baking sheet. Fill a small bowl with 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of olive oil and grab a pastry brush. Dip the brush into the oil and brush both sides of each crostini. Set each slice of bread so that it’s flat on the baking sheet. It’s okay if the individual pieces of bread are touching one another on the sides so long as they’re flat.

steps.headline: Bake your bread at 400 °F (204 °C) for 4-5 minutes on each side.
steps.description: Place your baking sheet in the middle rack of the oven and bake your crostinis until the bread is golden brown on each side. After 4-5 minutes of baking, take your sheet pan out of the oven and use a spatula or tongs to flip each crostini over. Bake for an additional 4-5 minutes.Tip: Complete the rest of the steps while your crostinis are baking. That way you’ll be able to put your crostinis together while they’re still warm!

steps.headline: Combine your cream cheese, horseradish, and dill in a bowl.
steps.description: If it isn’t already diced, mince your dill before combining your ingredients. Take 4 ounces (110 g) of cream cheese, 2 tablespoons (6.2 g) of dill, and 1 tablespoon (15 g) of horseradish and pour them into your bowl. Add salt and pepper if you’d like to season the mixture. Mix all of your ingredients together with a wooden spoon until they’re thoroughly combined. If you aren’t sure how much salt or pepper you want to add, opt for 0.25 teaspoons (1.5 g) of each. You can skip the salt altogether for a healthier treat.

steps.headline: Slice your salmon into thin 4–5 in (10–13 cm) deli slices.
steps.description: Take your smoked salmon out of the packaging. If it’s pre-cut, you don’t need to do anything. If it isn’t cut, grab a chef’s knife and cut thin slices out of your salmon until you have 24 individual slices. The size doesn’t necessarily matter since you’re going to fold them on top of the crostinis, but 4–5 in (10–13 cm) slices are a good choice. If you love the taste of smokes salmon, cut bigger slices so that they dominate the flavor profile.

steps.headline: Take your crostinis out of the oven and spread your sauce on top of them.
steps.description: Use an oven mitt to remove the bread from the oven once it’s done baking. Place your crostinis on a serving tray and use a butter knife to spread your horseradish and cheese sauce over each individual crostini.

steps.headline: Layer your slices of salmon on top of the crostinis and season to taste.
steps.description: Take each slice of smoked salmon and fold it on top of each crostini. Press each slice down a little bit to adhere it to the bread. Sprinkle your remaining dill on top of the crostinis. Add additional salt and pepper if you’d like. Any leftover crostinis will be good for 1-2 days. Store them in an airtight container in your refrigerator.

steps.headline: Mash your goat cheese with a fork and mix it with the yogurt.
steps.description: Put 0.5 ounces (14.1 g) of goat cheese in a bowl and use a fork to start separating and condensing it. Add 2 tablespoons (30 g) of plain yogurt and mix the combination together until it’s smooth and the goat cheese is fully mixed with the yogurt. You can get crumbled goat cheese if you’d like and skip the step on mashing it. You’ll still need to mix the ingredients together though.

steps.headline: Spread the cheese and yogurt over 2 slices of bread.
steps.description: Grab 2 slices of whole wheat, rye, or multigrain bread. Set them out on a plate and use a butter knife to spread the cheese and yogurt evenly over 1 side of each slice.Tip: You can really use any type of bread for your sandwich, but whole wheat, rye, or multigrain are the standard options. They’re also healthier than a lot of other breads.

steps.headline: Add your smoked salmon to 1 of the slices of bread.
steps.description: If your smoked salmon is pre-cut, you can simply layer it on top of one of the slices of bread. If it isn’t cut, use a chef’s knife to trim 1.25 ounces (35.5 g) of smoked salmon into 4-5 thin slices. Thinner slices are better than thicker slices, since smoked salmon can have kind of an odd texture in a sandwich if you bite into a big chunk of it.

steps.headline: Cut 1/4 of a cucumber into thin pieces and add them to your sandwich.
steps.description: Run a cucumber under cool water to clean it. Set it out on your cutting board and hold it down with your nondominant hand. Use a chef’s knife to slice 1/4 of the cucumber into 0.5–1 inch (1.3–2.5 cm) slices. Add them on top of your salmon.

steps.headline: Season your sandwich with lemon juice, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Take a lemon and cut it into 4-6 slices. Squeeze the lemon juice over your sandwich to give it some citrus flavor. Sprinkle a pinch of salt and pepper over your sandwich. You can also choose to add more salt and pepper or skip it completely. It’s all a matter of personal preference. Add your second slice of bread on top of the salmon and enjoy your sandwich! You don’t have to use all of the lemon. You can squeeze as much lemon juice over the sandwich as you’d like. Chives and dill are popular toppings that you can easily add to your sandwich. Your sandwich will be good for 1 day after you’ve made it. It won’t hold for much longer than that before the bread starts to get soggy and the yogurt sauce starts to go bad.

steps.headline: Put a simple platter together with some dill sour cream for dipping.
steps.description: On a platter, layer a few rows of thinly-sliced cold smoked salmon. Mix 0.25 cups (61 g) of sour cream with 2 teaspoons (0.5 g) of dill in a small bowl. Set the sour cream out in a small dipping bowl in the center of the platter. On the other side of the dip bowl, add some shallots, crackers, crostinis, and capers to pair with the smoked salmon. Guests can use the sour cream and dill as a dipping sauce, or use a knife to apply the sour cream to a cracker or crostini and make a simple open-faced treat!

steps.headline: Set out a variety of smoked salmons to let people compare.
steps.description: Since smoked salmon comes in a variety of different styles, each with their own unique flavors and seasonings, let your guests sample an assortment of salmons. On a large platter, set out some cold smoked salmon, lox, gravlax, and hot smoked salmon. Layer each variety on a plate in 4 rows and artfully fold the slices on top of one another. Set some crackers or mini-bagels out on a platter next to it with tomato slices, cream cheese, and capers. Pair your salmon platter with a salad or fresh vegetables to give people a variety of choices.

steps.headline: Create a breakfast platter for large groups in the morning.
steps.description: Get a large platter and layer slices of smoked salmon around the rim of the plate. Cut 2 lemons into thin slices and arrange the lemon slices along the inside of the salmon slices. Spread a few slices of red onions over the lemons. Then, scatter 0.25 cups (45 g) of drained capers over the onions. Season the entire plate with minced dill and pepper. In the center of the plate, place some sour cream or cream cheese in mixing bowl. Set out some crackers, bagels, or toast to give your guests multiple options. Scrambled, poached, or hard-boiled eggs pair really well with smoked salmon for a more filling breakfast. If you opt for hard-boiled eggs, peel them and set them out around the dip.

methods.name: Using Smoke Salmon in Other Dishes

steps.headline: Throw cold smoked salmon on top of a bagel with cream cheese.
steps.description: While lox is the popular option for salmon that goes on a bagel, you can use any type of smoked salmon instead. Toast a bagel and smear it with cream cheese. Take 1-2 thin deli slices of smoked salmon or lox and layer them on top of the cream cheese. For an additional flavor, add 2-3 slices of tomato.Tip: You can eat each half of your bagel separately, or you can put the 2 halves together and eat it like a sandwich. Replace the tomato with a few slices of avocado if you want a contemporary version of this snack.

steps.headline: Add smoked salmon to a salad.
steps.description: Smoked salmon makes an excellent addition to a salad. Hot smoked salmon works well with heartier vegetables like carrots and fennels, while cold smoked salmon can be used to replace chicken in most recipes. Use vinaigrette or poppy seed dressings instead of Caesar or ranch when building a smoked salmon salad. You can cut thin slices of salmon before adding it to a salad, or opt to shred it with a fork. You can also weigh it down with a heavy can or bowl before cutting it if you want to remove a lot of the juices. Smoked salmon doesn’t really work that well in salads that utilize a lot of fruit. Sweet flavors and fish don’t tend to work well with one another.

steps.headline: Create a smoked salmon dip that works well with bread or chips.
steps.description: Combine 2/3 cup (230 g) of crème fraiche and 2/3 cup (165 g) of plain Greek yogurt in a bowl. Add 4 teaspoons (20 g) of horseradish and mix the ingredients together. Blend 1 lb (0.45 kg) of thinly-sliced salmon in a food processor. Add the salmon to the yogurt mixture and mix them together to create a savory dip that will work with crostinis and chips alike. Add salt, pepper, or lemon juice to the top of the dip if you want to give it a more dynamic flavor profile. Your salmon dip will hold for 3-4 days if you store it in an airtight container in your refrigerator.

Cold smoked salmon refers to salmon that is smoked at any temperature lower than 80 °F (27 °C), typically for 15 hours or more.
